John Cage used an anechoic chamber when he wrote 4'33''. When he exited the room, he told one of the custodians that he heard 2 distinct sounds: 1 high and 1 low. The custodian responded that the high sound was the electricity channeling through the nervous system, and the low sound was the blood flowing through the body.

The moral of his piece, 4'33'', was that sound is always with us, even in complete silence.

i've recently had a mri scan done on my head. the scan itself was super quick, just like ten minutes, but afterwards(wearing sound proof headphones, head in a cage) they just left me in there for another 15-20 minutes. and that time was really weird. because i was so comfortable, i kind of lost feeling of my body. like when you just wake up from a nap, and dont feel your body until you start moving. it was like 7 am too, and i didnt go to sleep the night before until 3am, so i was super tired, and might have dozed off in there. so i was in this weird state of mind where everything is plausible. and one thought was like "am i....dead?" and i honestly couldnt tell. like, i was at the point where i wouldnt have been surprised if i were dead. scenes of people having epileptic attacks in mri machines started playing in my head, creepy pasta's started unravelling... but then they told me the scan was good and i was good to go lol.

what i was trying to say is that sometimes the brain jumps to conclusions waaay to easy.

What's interesting about this is it shows how little of what you hear is actually the direct sound from an object. Generally, the direct sound is what's used to localize something, but the reflections you hear from the first sound to about 80ms afterwards are what actually composes the bulk of what you perceive as the "sound" from something. From my experience, the direct sound is what's used to localize, while the indirect sound contains the actual perceived acoustic signature along with the cues as to the surrounding environment the source is in (i.e. small room, concert hall, outdoors, etc.). You can get a similar effect after it snows. Outside peoples voices sound muted compared to what you would normally hear. Of course, the above is the two extremes, where either all the sound is absorbed and there are no reflections, or allowed to reflect until its eventually attenuated by the losses in the air itself.

as someone who is intensely already aware of every sound my body makes all the time and I suffer from sensory overwhelm everywhere I go especially in large crowds, yes I hate shopping with a burning passion of a thousand suns, I one time came close to an anechoic chamber in the natural world.  Up in the mountains around Crater Lake in Oregon there was a spot devoid of natural sounds.  It was a low wind day so not much in the way of wind noise, no birds, no airplanes, no passing cars, no other people not a single sound and I Immediately fell into such a Zen like state, I just stood there in the middle of an open field and did nothing.  I enjoyed the silence so much, the depressurization in my head as you stated due to the lack of sound brought me so much inner peace that I have never since then ever found anywhere, I think I would love being in that chamber too much that they would need to call the cops to drag me out of there.  Just thinking about it makes me want to experience it so bad.  It is probably easier for me to just drive down to Crater Lake again a few hundred miles than to find an anechoic chamber anywhere in this desolate PNW shitty, I mean city... great video.  TBH it makes me want to build my own chamber in my house but my wife would never let me so the closest thing is our walk in closet, very quiet and peaceful.

Short term is fine… eventually the complete isolation will get to you. Once your sense of time goes, it’s not long before you start getting stir crazy. When things get too quiet, you begin hearing things like the blood pumping through the blood vessels in your ear… some find that hyper self focus disturbing as well.

Not everyone is affected the same way or to the same degree.

People who practice meditation may enjoy a room like this for a longer time than someone who lives in the middle of a big city.

There is a reason solitary confinement is considered cruel… imagine being forced to stay in one of these rooms for days.

I used to swim Night Navigation Dives as part of my military training. All you can see is the glowing of the depth gauge, compass, and watch (used as a timer). You can hear your own breathing, but not much else. Your body feels weightless in the water.

After a half hour or so it's COMMON to get a sense of panic brought on by the sensory deprivation (thoughts of sharks in the pitch-black water doesn't help).

The trick is to understand why it happens, and let it pass on its own. After several minutes of uneasiness, it tends to pass, and you continue mission.

I worked fr a company that had an anechoic chamber for testing. One of the engineers let me inside and asked if I wanted to be shut in with the lights off. He warned me that it might be a bit unsettling, so he only allowed 5 min. of total dark/quiet.
5 minutes was enough to let me know that total silence is NOT something my brain could process adequately to adjust. I swear I could hear the blood moving through my body. Swallowing, blinking, breathing, scratching an itch, all became the loudest sounds in my head. I thought I could 'feel' the silence. I guess what I felt was the absence of external pressure.
I didn't freak out, but that short time was quite enough.
